measured_by: Drift-diffusion model with variable drift rate and collapsing boundaries
justification: The paper uses a drift-diffusion model with variable drift rate and collapsing boundaries to explain decision-making in gap acceptance scenarios. The model captures the dynamic accumulation of evidence based on distance and time-to-arrival, reflecting the cognitive processes involved.

topic_or_construct: Time-varying evidence accumulation in driving decisions
justification: The authors adopt a variable-drift rate model where the drift rate is determined by linear combinations of time-to-arrival (TTA) and distance to account for the dynamic sensory information during driving decisions.

topic_or_construct: Evidence accumulation in complex driving tasks
measured_by: Customized evidence accumulation model incorporating time-varying perceptual evidence
justification: The paper introduces a customized model extending standard drift-diffusion models to incorporate dynamically changing perceptual quantities (distance and TTA) over time, illustrating its effectiveness in predicting driver decisions.

topic_or_construct: Urgency effect in left-turn driving decisions
justification: The urgency effect imposed by approaching vehicles is modeled via collapsing boundaries that decrease with the decreasing time-to-arrival, demonstrating a clear link between time-pressure and decision-making thresholds.
